thread.title: Pre-season form could mean lights out for Watts
thread.title_full: Pre-season form could mean lights out for Watts

title: Pre-season form could mean lights out for Watts
text:
Melbourne forward Jack Watts’ pre-season form won’t have guaranteed him a spot in Demons’ round 1 side  16am Source: FOX SPORTS MELBOURNE forward Jack Watts’ pre-season form won’t have guaranteed him a spot in the Demons’ round one side, with teammate Max Gawn conceding he is fighting for his spot. 
But ruckman Gawn has rejected suggestions of a lack of pre-season fitness or attitudinal issues with the 25-year-old, who’s coming off a career-best season. 
With a number of youngsters putting their hands up with strong pre-season efforts, Gawn said Watts is facing tough competition for his spot despite kicking 38 goals not missing a game in 2016. 
Rather than a certainty, Gawn described Watts as an “option” for selection when their season proper begins against St Kilda on March 25. 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
“There’s been some guys who’ve had some good pre-seasons around him,” Gawn told SEN on Tuesday. 
“Aaron Vandenberg, Sam Weideman, I think Goodie (coach Simon Goodwin) wanted to try out the two ruckmen this week. So just simply trying a few things around. 
“Round one, he’ll still be a viable option for us.” 
A fit Watts’ non-selection for the Demons’ pre-season opener against Western Bulldogs has prompted speculation he may be overlooked by new coach Goodwin. 
But Gawn backed Watts to continue his strong 2016 form this season and expected him to play in at least one of the remaining two pre-season matches. 
“He’s fit. He’s been training all pre-season,” Gawn said. 
“But for some reason or another he wasn’t picked in the 24 (against the Bulldogs). I’m sure that wasn’t based on because he wasn’t good enough to be in the 22. 
“I think that’s more based on some of the training things we’ve seen from other guys around him, like Sam Weideman and Aaron Vandenberg, who deserved a go. 
“The Jack Watts we saw last year will be the Jack Watts we see this year.” 
- AAP
